comment_text: What other weird ways can we cook food??
You should cook food using the arc furnace directly with the arc itself.

Friend of mine that I worked with awhile ago would double up the foil on his food so he could weld a scrap plate hot as could be and toss whatever (sandwich, tamale, enchilada, etc) right on it for about 3 minutes or so before we'd go to lunch. We used to do it on a running engine when out irrigating fields all day. Or if it was sunny, have a mylar emergency blanket piece in your lunch to set that lunch of yours on or in while in the sun; leave for about a half hour on a hot Idaho day out in the corn or alfalfa fields. Sometimes we'd go pick a potato or two and cook them up one of those ways if we didn't have a lunch. Wasn't the best but it worked if you were hungry and needed some energy to keep you going on an extra long day or if you'd forgotten your lunch.

GTAW = Gas tungsten arc welding aka Tig = Tungsten inert gas
SMAW = Shielded Metal arc welding aka Stick welding
FCAW = Flux cored arc welding aka Mig but no inert gas

The stuttering is a mix of a few things.  The wire feed speed is a bit too high and the angle/distance from the nozzle and the pan is just a bit off.  Also just drag welding without some sort of elliptical motion will result in a very domed weld instead of a flatter more uniform weld.

In fact I'd go so far as to say if you want to do this experiment again with the welder, you'd find it far more effective to simply run the current through tend to end on the pan using gator clips. Just a tip for the future. Everyone in contact with the welder (including people watching) really should be wearing eye protection because you can get a thing called “eye flash” which is basically a bad sunburn on the eyes. I’ve heard it’s like having grains of sand in your eyes that you can’t blink out. It’s not a thing that is going to happen every time but it’s pretty common. Obviously it’s your decision but I would strongly recommend it.
